messageBody:
Oliver:

The spacing looks great, and it works well in both font sizes.  Thanks for the time spent improving the kerning.

I hate to be a Johnny one-note, but am I the only person bothered by the altered form of "eat" in Kingsley?  Is there some reason the second part of the letter cannot be vertical as it is in the manual?  I find it too similar to "ooze."


oliver langan wrote:

When the penis enlargement ads start coming in Shavian and
Quickscript, we're really in trouble.

Speaking of which, I spent some time yesterday playing with a font
editor (I think I have mentioned it before: http://
fontforge.sourcefor ge.net/ ) and managed to figure out how to do
character pair kerning. This has been a huge problem with QS fonts,
for me at least, since spacing between He and short letters (for
example) would look as though a space was inserted.

So, I spent some time -- a lot of time actually -- converting the
'kingsley' font to a) use the conscript unicode block, b) have a
slightly large space, and c) have much better kerning between the
letter pairs. The results are really nice, I think:

(attempting to paste an image)




(smaller version)




Note the improved kerning in 'you' and 'rather' in the first sentence.  Do you think I went overboard with 'culture' in the last sentence?

The "l" appears too close to the vowel to my eyes.

I also noted that "belongs" is misspelled.  It contains a "t" that should not be there.  A few words later, the word "craftwork" is also mispelled to my ears - ("on" vowel after "r").

Using this method, it may be possible to make an almost-senior version of the same font.  In fact, if I can figure out the 'alternate glyphs' thing then I might be able to shoehorn half characters in as well.

That would be "fantabulous" as Eddie Izzard would say.


You may notice that the above text is from the QS manual.  My reason for doing this, in fact, is because I am attempting to convert the QS manual so that it might be displayed on the web, using (downloadable) unicode fonts.  The Kingsley font (and jerome too) is a close match for the writing in the manual, but when used to write more than a single word it just looked bad: now it looks much better, and with Unicode it is very easy to intermix quickscript and orthodox.  I will try uploading an in-progress PDF later today, if I am able to verify that it displays correctly on a machine without the font installed (the font is not ready for prime time, and I'd rather sit on it than have lots of different versions out there).

oliver


Paige
